title: Basic Settings for Voice AI Agents in iMash
lede: This guide covers the basic settings available for AI agents in Imash, including conversation length, idle messages, voicemail options, and features that improve natural conversation flow.

steps.title: Access the Settings Tab
steps.content:
1. Open the AI Agent Builder for a new or existing agent.
  2. Navigate to the Settings tab to configure advanced options.

steps.title: Configure Conversation Limits
steps.content:
• Conversation Length: Set the maximum length of the call in seconds. The agent will automatically end the call when this limit is reached.
  • Response Delay: Define how long the agent should wait before responding, to avoid interrupting users who pause mid-sentence.
  • Interrupt Threshold: Set the minimum number of words the user must say to interrupt the agent while it is speaking.

steps.title: Silence Timeout
steps.content: Configure how long the system should wait before automatically ending a call due to user inactivity. Default: 30 seconds.

steps.title: Idle Messages
steps.content:
1. Enable Idle Messages to send follow-ups if the user does not respond.
  2. Set the wait time (e.g., 8 seconds).
  3. Configure up to three idle messages, such as: ‚ÄúAre you still there?‚Äù or personalized ones like ‚ÄúHey Bob, are you still online?‚Äù.
  4. Custom variables from the conversation (e.g., user‚Äôs name) can be included in idle messages.

steps.title: Voicemail Settings
steps.content:
• Hang Up on Voicemail: End the call if voicemail is detected.
  • Leave a Message: Configure a custom voicemail message. Dynamic parameters from the conversation can be inserted.

steps.title: Enable Backchannel
steps.content: Backchannel adds natural filler words (e.g., ‚ÄúGotcha‚Äù, ‚ÄúUh-huh‚Äù) during conversations to make the agent sound less robotic. This feature is in beta but can significantly improve natural flow.

steps.title: Preemptive Generation
steps.content: When using a STT + TTS + LLM setup instead of a real-time model, enable this setting to allow the LLM to generate responses concurrently while the user is speaking. This can improve responsiveness and create a faster back-and-forth flow.
